reviewText:
It's a good Minesweeper remake! There are dozens of levels now instead of just three, Steam leaderboards to show off with, and the options and controls are just like how you remember them. (Plus, it's got a nice background track that sounds roughly like a cat playing Team Fortress 2.)

That being said, Minesweeper is much more boring than I remember it. It's mostly just a game of matching: spotting which numbers on the board are equal to the amount of adjacent tiles or flagged mines. The only real puzzle aspect to Minesweeper comes when you've spotted all the possible matches, and the only way to progress is to use some deductive reasoning on the remaining numbers. But no matter how hard you try, if there are too many mines clustered together in the wrong way, you're eventually going to have to start guessing, and that's ultimately Minesweeper's biggest downfall.

Luckily, Fine Sweeper gives you lives, so you can step on multiple mines on a level and still keep going. This introduces a completely new skill to the game: when stuck in a guessing situation, instead of just clicking and hoping you don't die, you have to pick the option that would give you the most useful information in a single click. It's a pretty nice touch and it feels like a good evolution of the game of Minesweeper.

But eventually the game starts cranking up the number of mines, enough to remind you of that one time you thought it would be hilarious to make a custom Minesweeper game with the maximum amount of mines, and then soon realized it was completely pointless and impossible. Despite the designer's attempts to balance the difficulty, it's inevitable in Minesweeper that you're going to have to guess a whole lot. But that's a problem with Minesweeper itself, and so this remake shouldn't really be held accountable for it.

Although, it makes me wonder if the level generator could have included a bot that plays through the stage before it is presented, to make sure there are no necessary guesses. Or if there could be seeded boards with an automatic first click that are verified possible without guessing. But even though Fine Sweeper doesn't go all-out in bringing Minesweeper into the HD age, it's still good enough to be worth your time if you were, or still are, a huge fan of the old Windows games; it is a notable improvement on them.

As much as I love minesweeper I just can't recommend this game. There isn't enough new and the new stuff isn't up to a good enough standard.

As soon as I saw this game on steam I had to buy it. I am a huge minesweeper fan and I just couldn't pass up a new version of it being released. However this game isn't much better than the original.

The main mode that this version features is a continuous mode. This mode continues going with levels of increasing difficulty. They basically increase the difficulty by growing the board size and adding more bombs. The score increases as a sum of all the levels you do and it measures the time you take on each level. This is incorperated into a high score system that lets you compare your score with friends and other people. This is a nice addition that gives a new reason to play minesweeper.

However the problem with this mode is that there is no way to save it. I found myself going on a continuous run for over an hour earlier today. At that point I was getting pretty tired of it. I would have liked to quit the game and continue it later. But this wasn't possible since the game offers no way of saving it.

But this isn't the biggest problem the game has. It is horrible to play as you get further into the game with bigger boards. It is basically a guessing game at this point. Very little skill is involved. This is because the game puts you in situations where no amount of skill will let you figure out where there is a bomb and where there isn't so instead you just have to guess and hope for the best. I know this was a problem in the original minesweeper, but it definitely wasn't as big as a problem as it is in this game. When you get later into the game, i'd say around level 30ish, you start having to guess so often! This wasn't a fun experience and it isn't in the true light of minesweeper to have to guess instead of use skill.

The game does attempt to counteract this problem in a way. They use a life system. You find lives under blocks that you clear on the level which you can add to your collection. Everytime you hit a bomb you loose a life. Some people that are perhaps less skilled at minesweeper may like this addition. But to a hardcore player who has been playing for a long time this isn't of much use to me. I would much prefer to have only one life. I would prefer it if they would fix the guessing issue instead of using this lazy alternative to fix it. They don't even have an option to disable the life system which I would have done.

What I used to love about the original minesweeper is the ginourmous size boards you could make and play on. Whenever I played it I used to make one of the biggest boards possible and then I would end up playing for about half an hour or so just on the one board. Fine sweeper features a similar mode to setup a custom sized board. But is no where near the scale that you can do on traditional minesweeper. In fact the boards are puny in size compared to the original. It's quite laughable to see it actually. Even when you go to the biggest scale possible. I have no idea why the developer limited it so much!

The options menu of the game is also extremely lacking. The only option of note is the audio sliders of which there is a seperate one for music and for other sounds. It's also probably worth noting that the music and sounds aren't particularly good in my opinion. I had them off for my entire time playing it. And the only other option there really is the nostalgic colours  option. That is it. They could at very least have some resolution options or something else!

There was only one thing in this game that I could find that may lead you to play this instead of the original minesweeper. The graphics. They are such an improvement over the classic original minesweeper. Although i'm sure you really need it to play a simple game like this. If only the developer could have put as much effort into making the game unique and work properly as they put in on the graphics!

Overall I cannot recommend this game. There are so many issues that it isn't actually fun to play. Theres not enough different for anyone to even consider playing it over the original. I am gonna go back to playing the original as well and I think you should to. I would also like to take the time here to recommend a great alternative to minesweeper that improves drastically on the original formula and of which I greatly enjoyed called hexcells". If your a minesweeper fan and your wanting something new go and try that instead of this game.

reviewText:
Fine Sweeper is, well, Minesweeper, but with some changes which I found to enhance the basic experience. The game is immediately familiar to anyone who’s played Minesweeper, and it also has a tutorial for anyone who hasn’t.

The main mode of the game is a “campaign” style mode – you basically start with a tiny board to clear, and each time you win you progress to a slightly more difficult board (the backgrounds and colors vary as well). Pretty soon (and I do mean soon, it doesn’t take long to progress through the early levels) you’ll be playing on boards even more difficult than the “Expert” boards from Minesweeper. As you play through the campaign, you earn points for each mine you flag and each board you clear – and you can compare your scores to other players’ on the leaderboards.

This leads me to my only complaint – there’s no way to save your campaign progress. When you quit the campaign, your score is reset. You can still start at the highest level you’ve unlocked, but your score starts at zero. A single save slot would allow you to continue the game through more than one session.

As you play, you randomly unlock and find lives, which are used up whenever you detonate a mine. This single-handedly fixes the main frustration I have with Minesweeper – there’s no second chance if you guess wrong. Of course, once you run out of lives your game is over, but at least some of the frustration has been alleviated.

Custom game boards are included, so you’re able to create your own challenges. And if you’re not a fan of the new lives mechanic, you can play in “Classic” mode to disable it. The developer has proven to be very responsive as well, pushing out updates quickly and regularly based directly on community feedback.

Fine Sweeper provides a comprehensive Minesweeper package and improves on the classic. It’s more than worth the low price point.

reviewText:
A nice presentation of Mine Sweeper with a couple of nice, new features.

Auto-Clearing Option:
If you right-click on a cleared tile with a number (indicating how many bombs in it's surrounding tiles), and you have that number of marked tiles surrounding this number tile, all un-marked tiles will auto-clear.  Just be sure you marked the right tiles or the revealed bomb will detonate.  If you do not have the correct number of marked/flagged tiles around a number tile you can safely right-click on it to hilight the surrounding tiles and no new tiles will clear.  This feature increases the flow of the game tremendously.

Health:
Each time you detonate a bomb, you will lose a heart.  Lose all of your heats and it's game over.  When clearing tiles, replacement hearts will randomly appear as well as extra heart tiles to increase your total number of hearts up to seven.  I really like this approach, but I feel the game is too generous with how many hearts it gives you.  This makes the game a bit too easy.  It removes the tension you normally get when you play classic Mine Sweeper and you don't know if you are a mouse-click away from your explosive doom.

Graphics:
Simple space background graphics.  The planets are drawn crudely.  Subtle animated smoke and dust effects when tiles are cleared and when bombs detonate.  There is room for improvement, however:  Early levels (below 35 or so) have fewer total tiles.  The smaller tile graphics from later levels are used in these early levels and scaled up.  This makes the graphics look soft.  After you reach level ~35 everything looks sharper because everything is displayed in actual size.  Separate, larger tiles should have been created for these early levels so the graphics could look just as sharp as they look in later levels.  The entire game download is under 60 megabytes.  The developer had no reason not to create an extra set of larger tiles.

Aside from the soft graphics I meantioned just one paragraph ago (Remember?), the presentation is decent.  It could have looked even better with more dynamic lighting.  The tiles in this game are all evenly lit making them look like they could have been presented on a 16-bit console (other than the smoke and particle effects).

The game does present some fun graphics pop-ups that appear with certain achievements along with animated fireworks.  If you have any achievements in Pinball FX2 you know exactly what I am talking about.

The game has modes other than classic mine sweeper, but I have not tried them yet.  I've reached level 38 in the main game and I can easily recommend this game for it's low price, clean presentation and the auto-clearing feature.

reviewText:
For those who've never run a Windows device, or are just too young to have really caught the original game in its prime, back in the day when you had to open a hatch and shovel coal in to power your PC, or sacrifice some of your blood into the little funnel on the top and get it to run for an extra 66.06 minute's worth of use, there were two games that were all the rage for everyone from the lowliest peasant to the wealthiest king, many of which would spend literally millions on a new machine just to play them and nothing else. I am of course talking about Solitaire and Minesweeper. Solitaire has already seen several enjoyable re-workings, but now it's Minesweeper's time to shine with a modern update in the form of Fine Sweeper. And you know what?... It ain't half bad.

Presented with a grid full of square panels that are hiding several mines underneath, you click on a panel and reveal some blank spaces and some numbers. Each number represents how many mines surround that tile, and based on that information, you must deduce the locations of every mine and avoid them as you click and remove all the unoccupied panels on the board. With each cleared grid, you move on to another that's either bigger and/or has more mines hiding from you. Make a mistake and you'll have a fully primed ball explode in your face. Do that several times, and it's game over.

The difference with this update is it's far more lenient than its original granddaddy. You now have hearts that allow you some breathing room where each heart will give you a free pass should you click on a mine, more of which can be found hiding under some random squares that can be used to replenish your stock and give you more room for mistakes. Or, alternatively, instead of using them you can save them in a bank and eventually cash them in for special, one-time use abilities to help you clear the board. And for hardcore score enthusiasts, this version has scoreboards for you, too, along with additional methods of play available to maximise that goal.

A little extra flair is added with some clean, appealing visuals (the grid and its surrounding boarder resembling the top-down dungeons from the original NES Zelda) and some funky bass licks to keep the mood up from stage to stage. It's all perfectly pleasant and functional and serves as a nice, relaxed, modern take on a fun but dated classic. I'm not sure how many stages there are, as I stopped at the 50 required for the achievements, but with multiple stages of increasing difficulty, a custom mode with sliding scales of variables, and a sweet little price to boot, for fans of Minesweeper, whatever your flavour is, this has you covered. Although, even in this updated version, clicking on the wrong mine in a final 50/50 situation and wasting the past 20 minutes of your life never stops hurting.

reviewText:
50 hours in and I think it's time to write a review. Been playing it on and off rather addictively for the last month or so, most of that due to my unrelenting addiction for minesweeper (and achievements) as well as just wanting to top those leaderboards to make my life seem less worthless...

This is the best minesweeper remake I've ever played, it is a hell of a lot better then the windows remake that was on the windows store (not sure if they actually made it) which was a tragedy, I don't cry (much) but playing that reduced me too tears and almost lead me down a road of drink and drugs. Like that one this too had pickups, which is an obviously new addition to the classic minesweeper formula and whilst I was pretty skeptical at first it's a very well incorporated addition unlike the other version. There is also classic mode where you only have 1 life and therefore you hit a bomb you die (just like in real life!).

This game has unlimited levelling (until I assume the board is literally just mines) but post level 60, odds are you're going to find it very hard to complete it. This put me off a little at first, since the game then revolved too heavily on luck and not skill but then if it'd be far too easy if everything was solvable by skill, there's not much to really make harder regarding skill in minesweeper.
The sheer difficulty of the higher levels have made me a much better player as I was forced to find new ways and rules to find bombs, which is something games won't normally do!

The graphics are nice but not too distracting and veer too far from the original minecraft, in other words there is nothing over the top and 'included because it's eye candy and omg luk at dem 4k textures'... Sounds are fine, bombs give a nice explosion (and leave a crater in the board) which can be quite unnerving when you're really focusing which brings a lot of tension to the game.

The devs seem to very active, I've seen a lot of activity in the forums from them and they seem to answer and adress the majority of problems that appear which is great. They seem to really care about the game and are not looking for quick monies, especially considering the price!

For £1.99 this is a steal, I think I got this in a greenlight bundle so I paid a lot less and feel like I robbed the devs and also took there clothes but I'd pay at least full price considering I've got 50 hours out of it and I don't feel like I'm going to be uninstalling anytime soon (#1 spot on the leader board here I come!). Even if you are not human and didn't enjoy the original minesweeper, you should still pick this up if you even have the very least bit of passing interest in minesweeper. Recent update made the earlier levels a lot easier so it starts off as a very casual game, perfect for wasting time!

reviewText:
Pixel Prophecy have updated the game and have with that fixed one of the major problems in the game (and a few others too!). I would like to say to anyone considering buying this game that this game is not a big Minesweeper overhaul or improvement: it just adds a neat little feature to it.

While my biggest complaint has been fixed, a few other do remain. This would include the lack of statistics (e.g. games played/won/lost; I do not mean a leaderboard), the ability to replay the same level (without the level regenerating), the ability to look at the board after having lost a game (to see what went wrong; currently a message box saying 'Game Over' is in the way) and lastly a fix for unsolvable levels.
These first three functions have been included in earlier versions of Microsoft Minesweeper, but the fourth one would definitely be a big improvement over Microsoft's game.

Of course, the game also has functions that Microsoft did not put in their game, namely multiple lives (clicking a mine does not end the current game) , online leaderboards, achievements and a variety of levels.

Perhaps that these things will be fixed/added with the next patch. But until then, I can say that I would recommend Fine Sweeper, keeping in mind that Microsoft Minesweeper is still a strong rival.

reviewText:
How good are you at coin flipping?

That's what the more advanced stages of this game hinge on.

In campaign mode, starting around level 20, you're not going to be able to sweep an entire board without guess work.  Granted, you're going to have better than 50/50 odds on lots of guesses, but many guesses are no more than straight coin flips.  At level 20, the game stops being about skill, and transforms into a game of luck, whether it's if you can run hot at coin flipping, or whether you're fortunate enough to encounter lots of arbitrary heart health drops when you get in trouble.  Reaching level 20 in campaign mode is elementary for a skilled player, and since your health is fully replenished every ten levels (you receive full health at the start of level 20), plowing through levels 1 through 19 becomes tiring and is a pointless chore (but a necessary chore since if you're aiming for a high score, starting at level 1 will earn you the most cumulative points).  In levels 1 through 19, there is no reason to be careful with your clicks, not only because of too frequent health drops, but because at level 20 you're going to get all your health back anyway.

The one quantifier which made the original Minesweeper competitive, speed, seems to be completely neglected in this game.  I can't see any correlation between how fast you can sweep a board and scoring a higher number of points.

I've played more Minesweeper in my life than I care to admit; my fastest time on Expert" in the Windows game is somewhere barely over 60 seconds.  As of the June 3rd writing of this review

reviewText:
For $1.99, this game is perfectly fine as-is. If you like MineSweeper than you already know exactly what you are getting. My only complaint is that the new additions actually make the game worse, in my opinion.

1. By adding a health mechanic, it adds more forgiveness with mistakes, but for seasoned MineSweeper players this only means that you can plow through certain parts that you would otherwise have to logic out.

2. The music is sub-par.

There are many far better games to play in this genre. HexCells is front and center for me. With Fine Sweeper, you can get yourself into situations where you have to guess where a mine is, where in games like HexCells there is NEVER a need for guessing.

Nothing makes Fine Sweeper stand above its predecessor, and the new additions sound good, but don't translate well into the game.

(04/10) - At least playable

So what has this game going for it? There has to be something as it´s based on a free game that is furthermore already installed on every windows pc out there.
Well, there is a mode with more lives so you don´t die instantly, tho as a hardcore Minesweeper lover, that´s nothing for me.
One thing they did well is the first click: it is guaranteed to give you a start, and yes while this is not really innovative as other games did it as well by already revealing an area at the start, it´s definetly a feature that´s missing in Minesweeper...

Tho they forgot to change the biggest flaw of Minesweeper. If they had done that, i´d blindly recommend the game to anyone who likes Minesweeper... but they didnt: You still have to guess.
The more mines you add, the higher the probability of you having to guess meaning that the later stages will have a near to 100% chance that you will need to guess AT LEAST once, if not more times.

And as in any game: the word random should not be able to describe the game. Be it Hearthstone (a Hearthstone referene from a Minesweeper review, yes i did it) or any other game, it will decrease the value by an extreme amount.
So no, i can´t recommend you to buy this game, as it´s essentially the same game as the free version you probably already have installed...

Note: You can´t tell me there is no algorithm for placing the bombs in a way that you don´t have to guess. Hexcells: Infinite" did it and they had a far more complex ruleset to work with. So yeah
date: i will just keep waiting until someone may eventually release this game without having to guess
